channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Palestinians Move to Join International Criminal Court, Defying Israeli and U.S. Warnings
item.description: President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority signed papers to join the court and other organizations, a move that could bring harsh sanctions.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority celebrated the 50th anniversary of the Fatah movement on Wednesday in the West Bank city of Ramallah.

item.title: World Briefing: Nigeria: Militants Attack Town
item.description: Gunmen opened fire in a town in northeast Nigeria, killing at least 15 people, witnesses and a security source said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Facebook Blocks Account of Liao Yiwu, Exiled Chinese Writer
item.description: The writer, who lives in Germany, said the social network suspended his account after he posted a picture of an anti-government Chinese demonstrator streaking.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON

item.title: AirAsia Flight 8501 Crash Highlights Booming Indonesia Airline Industry’s Safety Issues
item.description: There are renewed concerns that Indonesia cannot keep up with the ever-growing popularity of air travel as incomes rise and low-cost carriers multiply.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER and KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: U.S. Troops, Back in Iraq, Train a Force to Fight ISIS
item.description: American officials say the trainees will be ready to take on ISIS by mid-February.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Ayman Oghanna for The New York Times
item.media:description: American troops and equipment have begun arriving at Al Asad Air Base in Anbar Province. American commanders say their goal is to train 5,000 Iraqi recruits every six weeks.

item.title: Bribes Free Drug Kingpin in Afghanistan, Where Cash Often Overrules Justice
item.description: The United States extolled a leading opium dealer’s imprisonment as a sign that the Afghan authorities could establish law and order. Then the man paid millions to escape.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sánchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Afghan security force in a watch tower located inside an Afghan jail at Hese Awal Kohistan district in Kapisa, Afghanistan.

item.title: Yemen Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 23
item.description: There were no immediate claims of responsibility for the attack at a ceremony for the Prophet Muhammad’s birthday in the southern city of Ibb.
item.dc:creator: By SHUAIB ALMOSAWA

item.title: Greece Dissolves Parliament to Prepare for Early Elections
item.description: The vote, which is due to be held Jan. 25, will pit the prime minister’s party against a left-wing group opposed to recent austerity measures.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: 3 Chinese Police Officers Arrested in Migrant Worker’s Death
item.description: Images of Zhou Xiuyun, 47, struggling with a police officer, then lying motionless as the officer stood on her hair, set off widespread condemnation on social media sites.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hong Kong Police Criticized After 14-Year-Old’s Detention
item.description: The authorities have been accused of trying to intimidate young pro-democracy protesters and their families after a 14-year-old girl was detained on suspicion of drawing flowers in chalk near government headquarters and sent to a juvenile home.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: A bystander watches as the Hong Kong police stand guard after a 14-year-old girl was arrested for drawing flowers on what became known as the "Lennon Wall" during pro-democracy protests.

item.title: Chinese Court Orders 6 Companies to Pay $26 Million for Polluting
item.description: The fine was the biggest of any Chinese pollution case and seemed to signal that officials are trying to crack down on businesses that have degraded China’s land, water and air.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Putin's Way: How Putin Forged a Pipeline Deal That Derailed
item.description: Russia’s energy minister and its energy giant, Gazprom, helped shape a Bulgarian bill for a pipeline that President Vladimir V. Putin sought to keep Europe dependent on Russian gas.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY and JO BECKER
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin used Aleksei B. Miller, Gazprom’s leader, left, to press Bulgaria for a pipeline.

item.title: Dozens Killed in Yemen Suicide Bombing
item.description: A suicide bomber killed at least 33 people in central Yemen at a cultural center where students were celebrating a Muslim holiday, medical sources and a resident said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Prison Sentence for Maker of Documentary on Chinese Constitutional Rule
item.description: The filmmaker, Shen Yongping, was detained in April and formally arrested on June 4, the 25th anniversary of the military crackdown on student-led protesters in 1989.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: Five Guantánamo Prisoners Are Released to Kazakhstan
item.description: Three detainees from Yemen and two from Tunisia were transferred from the military prison in Cuba. With the move, there are 127 prisoners left.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER

item.title: World Briefing: Cuba: Dissidents Are Detained
item.description: The Cuban police detained several dissidents on Tuesday and thwarted an unauthorized political protest in the most significant crackdown on the opposition since Cuba and the United States agreed this month to normalize ties.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Searchers Pull AirAsia Plane Debris and Bodies From Java Sea
item.description: Rescue teams off the coast of Borneo found bodies and debris from the AirAsia plane that disappeared Sunday, but it remained unknown why the plane went down.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: Aleksei Navalny, Putin Critic, Is Spared Prison in a Fraud Case, but His Brother Is Jailed
item.description: Mr. Navalny was not jailed despite violating house arrest by trying to join an antigovernment rally. But in what was widely seen as the Kremlin punishing him, his brother Oleg was sentenced to three and a half years in prison in the fraud case.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Aleksei A. Navalny was not imprisoned despite violating house arrest, but his brother was.

item.title: Court Orders Arrest of Ex-Executive at Korean Airlines Over ‘Nut Rage’
item.description: Cho Hyun-ah, daughter of the airline’s chairman, may face charges of assaulting the crew of a flight she disrupted.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Journalists surrounded Cho Hyun-ah, a former Korean Airlines executive, at a court in Seoul on Tuesday.

item.title: Calls to Free Leading Cleric in Bahrain
item.description: Sheikh Ali Salman, who is the head of the main Shiite opposition al-Wefaq party, was taken into custody on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
